#Text=Levina Teerlinc
#Text=An Elizabethan Maundy , miniature by Levina
#Text=Teerlinc , c. 1560
#Text=Levina Teerlinc ( 1510s – 23 June 1576 ) was a Flemish Renaissance miniaturist who served as a painter to the English court of Henry VIII , Edward VI , Mary I and Elizabeth I .
#Text=She was the most important miniaturist at the English court between Hans Holbein the Younger and Nicholas Hilliard .
#Text=Her father , Simon Bening was a renowned book illuminator and miniature painter of the Ghent-Bruges school and probably trained her as a manuscript painter .
#Text=She may have worked in her father 's workshop before her marriage . [ 1 ]
#Text=Biography

#Text=Teerlinc was born in Bruges , Flanders ( which is now a part of Belgium ) in the 1510s , one of five daughters of renowned miniaturist Simon Bening and granddaughter of Catherine van der Goes ( closely related to Hugo van der Goes ) and Alexander Bening . [ 2 ] [ 3 ]

#Text=After marrying George Teerlinc of Blanckenberge in 1545 , Teerlinc left for England , and is documented there by 1546 , when she became court painter to the Tudor court , serving Henry VIII , Edward VI , Mary I , and Elizabeth I .

#Text=She received an annual salary of £40 from 1546 until her death in 1576 , as granted by Henry VIII [ 4 ] and recorded by Lodovico Guicciardini ( 1567 ) , [ 4 ] which was more than was provided to Holbein . [ 5 ]
#Text=She was the only female painter in the court of Henry VIII . [ 6 ]
#Text=In 1559 Teerlinc was appointed tutor in painting to the King 's daughter at the Spanish Court . [ 7 ]
#Text=She and her husband had one son , Marcus . [ 8 ]
#Text=She died in Stepney , London on 23 June 1576 . [ 9 ]
#Text=Works
#Text=Portrait of Elizabeth I by Levina Teerlinc , c. 1565
#Text=No extant works by Teerlinc are currently identified . [ 10 ]

#Text=Yet she was one of the most well-documented artists at court in miniature painting , providing various portraits of Elizabeth I in the years 1559 , 1562 , 1563 , 1564 , 1567 ( " a full-length portrait " ) , 1568 ( " with Knights of the Order " ) , 1575 ( " with other personages " ) , and 1576 . [ 3 ]
#Text=She also painted for Mary I in 1556 " as a New Year gift a small picture of the " trynitie .
#Text=" [ 4 ]

#Text=A 1983 exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum represented  the first occasion when a group of miniatures has been assembled which can be attributed to Levina Teerlinc " . [ 5 ]

column1: #Text=Since the exhibition also performed the same function for her predecessor as court miniaturist , Lucas Hornebolte , it was especially useful in developing consensus on attributions .

#Text=Five miniatures and two illuminated manuscript sheets were in the group , including a miniature of Lady Katherine Grey from the V&A , and others from the Yale Center for British Art , the Royal Collection ( both of these possibly of the young Elizabeth I , and private collections ) .

#Text=Strong considered there was " a convincing group of miniatures that emerge as the work of a single hand , one whose draughtsmanship is weak , whose paint is thin and transparent and whose brushwork loose " . [ 5 ]
#Text=She also probably designed the Great Seal of England for Mary I and the earliest one used by Elizabeth ( in the 1540s ) . [ 7 ]
#Text=Partial list of works
